National Educational Radio
A DIVISION OF THE NATIONAL ASSOCIATION OF EDUCATIONAL BROAD CASTERS
1346 Connecticut Avenue N.W. Washington D.C. 20036 Telephono 667-6000
EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR
robert a. mott January 23, 1969
Mr. Donald R. Quayle
General Consultant
Corporation for Public Broadcasting
555 Madison Avenue
New York, New York 10022
Dear Don:
As you requested via telephone, a proposal has been
prepared detailing the costs of relocating the Nat¬
ional Educational Radio Tape Network from Urbana,
Illinois to Washington, D. C.
After you have reviewed the proposal, I would like
the opportunity to discuss it with you in greater
detail.
Timing is of the essence in this proposal. I am
confident that if the Corporation sees fit to approve
funds for this project, it will set in motion a chain
of actions that will be extremely beneficial to public
radio.
It should be made clear that I envision this proposal
as one of a series. Other logical steps that would
be appropriate as funds become available include the
re-establishment of the NERN Public Affairs Bureau,
development of a national production center, initiation
of live radio networking to a group of non-commercial
radio stations.
A revised proposal to replace our submittal in Sept¬
ember, 1968, requesting funds for the NERN Public Affairs
Bureau is now being prepared and will be in your hands
in the near future.
I look forward to seeing you on January 28. Perhaps
we’ll have an opportunity to discuss aspects of the
various documents I’ve submitted recently.
Sincerely,
Robert A. Mott
